info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued April 10 at 6:14PM PDT by NWS Reno
info.description: ...Potent Late Season Winter Storm with High Winds and Sierra Snowfall Monday Followed by Sub-Freezing Temperatures... * An incoming Pacific storm is still expected to move into the area tomorrow. High winds, localized fire weather concerns, areas of blowing dust, snow for the Sierra and western Nevada foothills, and much cooler conditions are all on tap with this storm. * Winds: High winds with potentially damaging gusts of 60 mph or more will materialize by Monday morning with the strongest winds targeting wind prone sections of the Highway 395 and Interstate 580 corridor across western Nevada and Mono County. Sierra ridge wind gusts are forecast to be near and above 100 mph. Blowing dust may reduce visibility at times across Pershing, Churchill, and Mineral counties. Conditions on area lakes will be hazardous to small vessels. * Snow: Snow will impact travel in the Sierra and northeast California by early tomorrow morning, with rain and snow spreading into western Nevada lower elevations late tomorrow afternoon through the evening hours. Snowfall amounts of 8 to 14 inches are forecast near the Sierra crest, with up to 8 inches down to the Tahoe basin and southward into western Mono County. Across the remainder of western Nevada, snowfall will generally be an inch or less. * Temperatures: High temperatures early this week will be more than 30 degrees colder compared to last week`s warm spell, with widespread hard freezes likely both Monday and Tuesday nights. Now is the time to prepare for this significant change back to winter weather. Secure loose outdoor items before the winds increase tomorrow, and have sufficient food, water, warm clothing and emergency supplies handy in case of power outages. Anyone planning travel in the Sierra Monday through early Tuesday can expect slick travel conditions and delays with chain controls. Bring inside or cover any cold sensitive plants.
